image.altText: A man with a serious expression wearing black glasses and a navy NT Police uniform looks off camera.

items.synopsis: Jamie Chalker left his role as NT police commissioner suddenly in March, and never returned. The NT government is refusing to release a letter which allegedly helps explain why.

title.children: NT government criticised for refusing to release 'secret letter' sent to ex-top cop before legal battle

image.altText: an image of a middle aged woman with brown hair wearing a coloured shirt

items.synopsis: It's the most common genetic disorder in Australia that leaves people tired and lethargic, but you've probably never heard of it.

title.children: Denise was fighting daily exhaustion and pain. Giving blood was the answer

image.altText: a man wearing a cap looking at the camera and smiling

items.synopsis: Johnson Kokozian is denied bail after being charged over a crash in Sydney's south-west that killed a brother and sister.

title.children: Driver charged over crash that killed siblings in Sydney ‘extremely upset’ over deaths, court told

image.altText: Dutton walks through a crowd wearing Liberal blue shirts.

items.synopsis: A commitment by Liberal Party leader Peter Dutton to hold a second referendum on Indigenous recognition has been rubbished by one of the leading conservative Voice campaigners.

title.children: Dutton criticised by 'Liberals for Yes' group over pledge for second Indigenous recognition referendum

image.altText: The chair of ASIC, James Shipton, during a press conference.

items.synopsis: If this matter wasn't so serious, Treasury's responses to former ASIC chairman James Shipton's letters about his experience at the regulator would make rich material for an episode of the British political satire Yes Minister, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: Former ASIC boss said his job led him to despair. What happened next was like an episode of Yes Minister

image.altText: A qantas plane taking off into a clear blue sky with a city skyline at the bottom in the distance

items.synopsis: August was meant to be the month where Qantas would prove it had done the impossible after the pandemic devastated the airline. Instead, it spent a week embroiled in controversies that won't be Alan Joyce's responsibility to clean up.

title.children: Qantas is no stranger to turbulence, but it's flown headfirst into controversies it didn't see coming

image.altText: Two brunette women sit on the floor of a lounge room looking at each other smiling while patting a dog that lay on the ground

items.synopsis: Erica Packer, former wife of billionaire James Packer, opens up about the deadly genetic mystery shadowing her family and the scientists working to crack the code for thousands more Australians.

title.children: Nearly all the women in Erica Packer's family have died from breast cancer. And she doesn't know why

image.altText: A man looking at a destroyed vehicle near a road.

items.synopsis: Progress in Ukraine's counteroffensive has been slower than expected, but its forces are building momentum in the country's south, and could be just 15 kilometres away from a major prize.

title.children: 'The enemy's defence is cracking': Why Ukraine could be just 15km from major war breakthrough

image.altText: A firefighter works at a site which was hit during Russia's drone attacks in Odesa.

items.synopsis: Russian drones hit a port that is critical to Ukraine's grain exports, injuring at least two people in the attack on southern parts of the Odesa region, Ukrainian officials say.

title.children: Russian drones strike critical Ukrainian port ahead of key grain deal talks between Putin and Turkey's president

image.altText: hands hold colourful leaflets that read Tes 23

items.synopsis: As the campaign for the Voice referendum begins, it's worth having a look at why this referendum question has become so hopelessly ensnarled in undergrowth. And perhaps doing a spot of weeding, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: The referendum is a Yes/No vote on 92 words. All other disputes should be shut out

image.altText: mud covers the ground at the site of the Burning Man festival.

items.synopsis: Authorities in Nevada are investigating a death at the site of the Burning Man festival where thousands of attendees remained stranded from flooding.

title.children: One confirmed dead as Burning Man festival-goers trapped in desert after rain floods site

image.altText: a man in a yellow t-shirt faces a man in a red t-shirt

items.synopsis: Zimbabwe's former cricket captain and all-time Test wicket-taker had been undergoing treatment for cancer in Johannesburg.

title.children: Zimbabwe cricket great Heath Streak dies aged 49

image.altText: A woman holds onto her head and a second woman tries to fix her upside down umbrella

items.synopsis: The typhoon is the first one in four years to directly hit Taiwan.

title.children: Typhoon Haikui hits Taiwan forcing thousands to evacuate and cancelling flights

image.altText: A blue F1 car exits a corner as a red F1 car enters the corner.

items.synopsis: Max Verstappen's legacy as one of Formula 1's all-time greats has been enhanced after the Dutchman claimed a record 10th consecutive grand prix victory.

title.children: Verstappen makes it a perfect 10 with record breaking win

image.altText: Nick Eyles looks at the camera in an open air setting.

items.synopsis: A mining company wants to explore Nick's farm for rare earth elements — but he's worried about what would happen to his farm if exploration turns into actual digging.

title.children: A mining company wants to explore Nick's farm, but he's worried — what happens if they find something?

image.altText: Morrison sits on the green bench in the back row of parliament with his arms crossed

items.synopsis: In years gone by, former prime ministers were often trusted confidants to their successors. Not so these days, when the trend has been for former leaders to make a swift exit from the parliament, writes Paul Strangio.

title.children: When PMs are booted from leadership, they typically opt to leave parliament. So why hasn't Scott Morrison?

image.altText: Patty Mills holds a basketball in one hand

items.synopsis: Australia puts aside any disappointment over missing a shot at a medal at the FIBA World Cup with a comfortable 100-84 victory over Georgia in Okinawa.

title.children: 'You haven't seen the best of us': Boomers end World Cup campaign with win over Georgia

image.altText: A man shelters under a small stool from hail.

items.synopsis: From drought and bushfires to hail storms and flooding, El Niño's official declaration for the first time in eight years is likely to bring it all. Or maybe not. We look back at the impacts the major climate driver has brought to Australia in the past.

title.children: How might this year's potential El Niño compare to previous events?

image.altText: A young girl sits at a table smiling. A worksheet is in front of her

items.synopsis: At a school near Alice Springs, children and their parents are learning the severely endangered language of Pertame. It's just one example of a national push to revitalise Indigenous languages for the next generation.

title.children: This Indigenous language has just 20 fluent speakers left. This playgroup aims to save it

image.altText: It's been a tough week for QLD fire crews and it's about to get tougher.

items.synopsis: Large swathes of eastern and central Australia are already on high alert this spring, after the country's warmest winter on record.

title.children: Catastrophic fire danger declared for parts of Queensland as Australia enters warm, dry spring

image.altText: Anthony Albanese meets with Manasseh on sidelines of the Pacific Islands Forum.

items.synopsis: Australian security forces will remain in the Pacific nation until June to assist with an election.

title.children: Australia to extend security mission in Solomon Islands

image.altText: A group of protesters in blue shirts stand on a street, in the centre a man with an Israeli flag on his hip, smoke behind him

items.synopsis: The confrontation was one of the most violent among African asylum seekers and migrants in Tel Aviv in recent memory, with 30 police officers among the injured and three protesters hit by police fire.

title.children: More than 100 injured as Eritrean groups and police clash in Tel Aviv

image.altText: An Ipswich Community Youth Service teacher and student look at a book together

items.synopsis: West of Brisbane, this 16-year-old was vandalising cars and spent time in a watch house. An innovative education program has him on a brighter path.

title.children: 'When I don't have stuff to do, I do stuff that's naughty': Young offenders find a better path

image.altText: The peak of a rocky mountain, with blue sky and cloud visible behind it.

items.synopsis: Four teenagers have been rescued atop the popular mountain in Stirling Range National Park, in WA's Great Southern region.

title.children: Four teens rescued after climbing Bluff Knoll mountain amid poor weather conditions

image.altText: A boat floats in the water near a Chinese ship.

items.synopsis: In the face of a David and Goliath battle to maintain control over the islands of Kalayaan, which are still administered by Manila, in the South China Sea, the Philippines has turned to two very different forces: soldiers and holiday makers.

title.children: The Philippines is in a David and Goliath battle with China. But has Manila found a sneaky workaround?

image.altText: A woman wearing glasses with a bookcase behind her.

items.synopsis: The federal government extends its national rollout of endometriosis and pelvic pain clinics in a bid to improve diagnosis times and treatment.

title.children: New endometriosis clinics announced for Adelaide, Sydney

image.altText: Julia Baird, who is wearing a blue swim cap and goggles submerged in the sea, looks back at the shore in warm morning sunlight

items.synopsis: For awe hunters, the everyday is often the extraordinary and the smallest wonders can be transformative. Their secrets can be yours, too — you just need to open your eyes.

title.children: On dark days, through chronic illness, hunting awe has saved me. It can transform your life, too

image.altText: Jack Williams celebrates

items.synopsis: The Sharks will meet the Roosters at Shark Park after beating the Raiders, who had Seb Kris sent off and will now travel to Newcastle in week one of the finals. Earlier, the Titans beat the Bulldogs in a shoot out on the Gold Coast.

title.children: NRL finals schedule set as Sharks secure home advantage with victory over 12-man Raiders — as it happened

image.altText: Chloe Molloy smiles as a number of her Swans teammates gather around her

items.synopsis: The North Melbourne Tasmanian Kangaroos score the first 37 points of the game and keep St Kilda scoreless in the first half on their way to recording a 40-point opening round win.

title.children: Swans storm home to claim maiden AFLW win and stun local rival Giants

image.altText: An old man wearing a suit looking stunned and sad being talked to by a man while a woman grabs his arm

items.synopsis: A senator's troubling freeze-up in front of the cameras this week has fuelled a national conversation about whether America's politicians are too old.

title.children: After an elderly senator's freeze-up, the US debates how old's too old to govern

image.altText: Infra red image of the whirlpool galaxy

items.synopsis: It's been almost two decades since an image of the M51 galaxy was captured in high clarity.

title.children: James Webb telescope captures stunning new image of 'Whirlpool galaxy'
